Name: 2,4-DIBROMOPHENOL
Description: 2,4-dibromophenol is a bromophenol that is phenol in which the hydrogens at positions 2 and 4 have been replaced by bromines. It has a role as a marine metabolite. It is a bromophenol, a dibromobenzene and a brominated flame retardant.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Whitfield FB et al; Wat Sci Tech 25: 131-138 (1992)
plant_concentrations.Value: Concentrations of 2,4-dibromophenol were measured in brown algae (6.1 to 25 ug/kg wet weight), red algae (1.9 to.4 ug/kg), bryozoa (6.7 and 8.3 ug/kg) and a hydroid (21 ug/kg) collected from Exmouth  Gulf, Australia, in October 1990(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Whitfield FB et al; Wat Sci Tech 25: 131-138 (1992)
animal_concentrations.Value: Concentrations of 2,4-dibromophenol were measured in sponges (2.1 to 110 ug/kg) collected from Exmouth Gulf, Australia, in October 1990(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Whitfield FB et al; Wat Sci Tech 25: 131-138 (1992) (2) Whitfield FB et al; Wat Sci Tech 31: 113-120 (1995) (3) Whitfield FB et al; J Agric Food Chem 46: 3750-57 (1998) (4) Whitfield FB et al; J Agric Food Chem 45: 4398-4405 (1997) (5) Chung HY et al; J Agric Food Chem 51: 6752-6760 (2003)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Endeavour prawns from Exmouth Gulf, Shark Bay, and Groote Elylandt, Australia, contained 2,4-dibromophenol at concentrations of 58 to 200, 160, and 31 ug/kg, respectively(1). Ten different species of fish, collected in August 1992 from the eastern coast of Australia, contained 2,4-dibromophenol at concentrations of <0.05 to 2.0 ng/g for the carcass and <0.05 to 150 ng/g for the whole gut (analysis of single fish from each species)(2). Ocean fish were separated by species into pelagic carnivores, benthic carnivores, diverse omnivores and restricted omnivores; concentrations in the flesh ranged from <0.01 to 1.2 ng/g, <0.01 to 23 ng/g, <0.01 to 2.0 ng/g, and 0.2 to 0.5 ng/g, respectively, while concentrations in the gut ranged from <0.01 to 3.3 ng/g, <0.01 to 320 ng/g, 0.1 to 150 ng/g, and 2.5 to 26 ng/g, respectively(3). Thirty samples of 9 species of prawns, collected from the eastern coast of Australia from 1993 to 1996, contained 2,4-dibromophenol at concentrations of 0.20 to 1100 ng/g(4). 2,4-Dibromophenol concentrations in cultivated prawns ranged from <0.01 to 0.59 ng/g(4). 2,4-Dibromophenol was detected in marine fish, mollusks, and crustaceans obtained from a seafood shop in Hong Kong. Seasonal concentrations in the flesh of rabbitfish (Siganus canaliculatus) and brown-spotted grouper (Epinepheus areolatus) ranged from 0.727 to 9.47 ng/g and 0 to 5.36 ng/g, respectively; in the gut, concentrations ranged from 3.41 to 97.1 ng/g and 4.63 to 31.4 ng/g, respectively. In the mullusks, including clams (Tapes philippinarum) and oysters (Ostrea rivularis), seasonal concentrations ranged from 2.54 to 195 ng/g and 9.80 to 52.9 ng/g, respectively. For crustaceans, seasonal concentrations in the cephalothorax and tail of the shrimp (Penaeus japonicus) ranged from 1.78 to 10.4 ng/g and 0 to 6.78 ng/g, respectively; in crab (Charybdis feriatus), concentrations ranged from 27.6 to 214 ng/g(5).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Tolosa I et al; Marine Pollut Bull 22: 603-7 (1991) (2) Watanabe I et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 35: 272-78 (1985)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Surficial sediments from the Rhone estuary, collected in 1987/1988, contained 2,4-dibromophenol at concentrations of 7 to 5,848 ng/g, dry weight basis, from 5 sampling sites(1). Upper river and marine sediment layers in Osaka Prefecture, Japan, collected in 1981 through 1983 at 12 different locations, contained 2,4-dibromophenol at concentrations <0.2 ppb (dry weight basis)(2).
